Context:
Program Name: Business
Code: B125
Credential: Ontario College Diploma
Duration: 2 years (4 semesters)
Method of Study: Full-time
Starting Months: January, September
Domestic Tuition: $3,626.00 *
International Tuition: $17,925.00 **
Location: St. James Campus
Program Availability:
- Fall 2024: Open (Domestic and International)
- Winter 2025: Open (Domestic and International)
Add to Comparison: +
Compare Programs: Compare Programs
Related Programs: Business Administration (B145), Business – Marketing (B120), International Business Management (Postgraduate) (B411)
Program Description: The Business two-year diploma program provides students with the tools to perform business functions at a local, national, and global level. Graduates can look forward to career opportunities such as customer service representative, junior business analyst, or scheduling coordinator.
Skills gained after completion of the program include using an environmental scan to identify and discuss the impact of global issues on an organization's business opportunities, enhancing business performance through ongoing personal and professional development, implementing principles of corporate sustainability, social responsibility, and ethics, and contributing to the planning, implementation, and monitoring of projects.
Accreditation: The Centre for Business program is part of the School of Management. The college is accredited by ACBSP. 

*Domestic tuition may vary depending on the province of residence.
**International tuition is subject to change.

Context:
The Centre for Business at George Brown College has fourteen programs accredited by the Accreditation Council for Business Schools and Programs (ACBSP). These programs include advanced diploma and diploma levels in Accounting and Finance, Human Resources, Management, and Marketing, as well as the Honours Bachelor of Commerce (Financial Services) program in Accounting and Finance. George Brown is one of only two colleges in Ontario to have earned ACBSP accreditation.

Students have the option to earn a business elective credit through the Field Education Course (BUS 1067). Graduates of the Business program find work in various employment settings such as manufacturers, retailers, financial institutions, government offices, consulting firms, and other businesses. Possible career opportunities include customer service representative, junior business analyst, procurement assistant, project planning assistant, and scheduling coordinator.

The B125 program requires students to complete 27 courses to graduate. This includes 23 mandatory courses, one business elective or field education course, and three general education electives. Students may need to take prerequisite courses such as COMM 1000 (Introduction to College Communication) and MATH 1027 (Business Math with Remediation), which do not count toward the 27 courses required for graduation. George Brown students must complete three general education courses from at least two of the following categories: Social Sciences, Arts and Humanities, or Science and Technology. Students are required to make up any failed or dropped courses.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Business Program B125 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
The text provides information about the course offerings for a business program at a college, divided into four semesters. Each semester lists the course codes, names, and any prerequisites required. The courses offered include Business Concepts I (BUS 1038), Communicating Across Contexts (COMM 2000), Business Computer Applications I (COMP 1010), Principles of HR Management (HRM 1008), and many others. Some semesters have elective courses to choose from, as noted in the text.

The students are required to make up any failed or dropped courses before graduation and can do so during daytime or evening through Continuing Education. They should check with the business office staff to ensure that the Continuing Education courses are equivalent to those offered in the full-time program. Some courses may not be available in every semester. The text also mentions that staff can assist students with any special timetable requirements they may have.

FACTUAL INFORMATION:
1. Students must make up failed or dropped courses before graduating.
2. Continuing Education courses are an option to make up missed courses.
3. Business Concepts I (BUS 1038) is a required course in semester 1.
4. Communicating Across Contexts (COMM 2000) is a required course in semester 1.
5. Business Computer Applications I (COMP 1010) is a required course in semester 1.
6. Principles of HR Management (HRM 1008) is a required course in semester 1.
7. Some courses may not be available every semester.
8. Professional Communications I (COMM 1034) is a required course in semester 2, with a prerequisite of COMM 2000.
9. Business Computer Applications II (COMP 1115) is a required course in semester 2, with a prerequisite of COMP 1010.
10. Microeconomics (ECON 1031) is a required course in semester 2.
11. Project Management (BUS 1040) is a required course in semester 2.
12. Organizational Behaviour (PSY 1129) is a required course in semester 2, with no prerequisites.
13. Macroeconomics (ECON 1032) is a required course in semester 3.
14. Professional Selling (MARK 1002) is a required course in semester 3.
15. Principles of Accounting (ACCT 1036) is a required course in semester 3.
16. Operations Management (MGMT 4009) is a required course in semester 3, with prerequisites of MATH 1008 and COMP 1115.
17. Business Statistics (MATH 1012) is a required course in semester 3.
18. Career Planning and Development (STS 1037) is a required course in semester 3, with no prerequisites.
19. Students must choose one General Education Elective for each semester.
20. Managerial Accounting (ACCT 2031) is a required course in semester 4, with a prerequisite of ACCT 1036.
21. Small Business Management (BUS 1041) is a required course in semester 4, with no prerequisites.
22. Business Law (BUS 1044) is a required course in semester 4, with no prerequisites.
23. Supply Chain Management II (MGMT 2049) is a required course in semester 4, with prerequisites of MGMT 4009 and COMP 1115.
24. Students must choose one General Education Elective for semester 4.

Context:
Program Offered: Chain Management II (MGMT 4009 & COMP 1115)
General Education Electives: CODE, COMM 1034 (mentioned multiple times), CMMK 1114, CMMK 1127, CMMK 1156, CMMK 1113, COMP 1010, MGMT 2036, MARK 1020, HRM 2027, HRM 1008
Pre-requisite for Business Elective: BUS 1067
Field Education Course: By application only – contact the Centre for Business office, CMMK 1114

Program Learning Outcomes:
- Identify and discuss the impact of global issues on an organization’s business opportunities by using an environmental scan.
- Apply principles of corporate sustainability, corporate social responsibility and ethics to support an organization’s business initiatives.
- Use current concepts/systems and technologies to support an organization's business initiatives.
- Apply basic research skills to support business decision-making.
- Support the planning, implementation and monitoring of projects.
- Perform work in compliance with relevant statutes, regulations and business practices.
- Explain the role of the human resource function and its impact on an organization.
- Use accounting and financial principles to support the operations of an organization.
- Describe and apply marketing and sales concepts used to support the operations of an organization.
- Outline principles of supply chain management and operations management.
- Outline and assess the components of a business plan.
- Develop strategies for ongoing personal and professional development to enhance work performance in the business field.

Tuition & Fees:
- Domestic Tuition: $3,626.00
- International Tuition: $17,925.00
Additional Costs: Estimated total of tuition, materials, student service and ancillary fees for the first two semesters of programs starting in Fall 2023/Fall 2024. Subject to change for programs starting in later dates. Does not include books which are to be purchased by the student separately.

Context:
* Programs starting in Fall 2024 have estimated service and ancillary fees for the first two semesters.
* Tuition fees are subject to board approval.
* Material, student service and ancillary fees are estimated based on prior years but are subject to change without notice.
* Fees do not include books which students must purchase separately.
* International Students should visit the International Fees and Related Costs page for more information.
* Financial Assistance: The program is approved for OSAP funding for applicants who meet OSAP eligibility criteria.
* Admission Requirements: Applicants need an Ontario Secondary School Diploma or equivalent, grade 12 English (C or U), and grade 11 Math (C, M or U) or grade 12 (C or U). Mature students may take the Admissions Assessment for English and Math or consider upgrading.
* Some college and university credits may qualify for exemptions. Applicants should visit the transfer guide for more information.
* Proficiency in English communications is necessary for success in the program. Students should review the English proficiency requirements.
* International students should apply through the George Brown College Online Application System. Domestic students should apply through Ontario Colleges.
* Information sessions are held on a regular basis, where applicants can have questions answered and learn about program content, career options, professors and staff.

Context:
The text provides information on how to contact George Brown College for various inquiries related to admissions, fees and financial information, and advising. It also mentions specific contacts for international student admissions and the Centre for Business. The programs are offered at the School of Management and classes usually take place at the St. James Campus, specifically at 200 King St. E. and 290 Adelaide St. E., Toronto, Ontario, Canada. Campus tours can be signed up for and virtual tours are available. The Centre for Business can be contacted via email at business@georgebrown.ca or phone at (416) 415-5000 ext. 2160. For inquiries related to specific programs, contact the program coordinator Charlotte Goldfried at charlotte.goldfried@georgebrown.ca. International students can contact international recruitment representatives by booking a virtual meeting or submitting an inquiry through the International Contact Us page. Financial inquiries can be made to the Financial Aid Office at FinAid@georgebrown.ca or by visiting the Financial Aid section. For general admissions inquiries, contact the Admissions Office at admissions@georgebrown.ca or visit the Admissions section.

Extracted Information:
- Contact information for George Brown College (Admissions Office: admissions@georgebrown.ca, Financial Aid Office: FinAid@georgebrown.ca, Centre for Business: business@georgebrown.ca)
- Campus locations (St. James Campus, 200 King St. E., 290 Adelaide St. E.)
- Contact information for international student recruitment representatives and FAQ page
- Program offered at the School of Management
- Financial aid and scholarship inquiries
- Contact information for Entry Advisors and FAQ page
- Contact information for Centre for Business (email: business@georgebrown.ca, phone: (416) 415-5000 ext. 2160)
- Contact information for program coordinator Charlotte Goldfried (email: charlotte.goldfried@georgebrown.ca)
- International student inquiries through country-specific representatives or International Contact Us page
- Campus tours and virtual tour availability.
